questions.text: What does the Greek word planetes mean?

answerChoices.text: wanderer
large mass
orbit
sphere

questions.text: The ancient Greek definition of a planet was:

answerChoices.text: An object that appears at different points in the celestial sphere.
A large spherical mass orbiting the sun
A large spherical mass moving in an ellipse around the earth
Any large mass in space

questions.text: Retrograde Motion refers to what phenomenon?

answerChoices.text: A planet slows down and stops moving.
The earth slows down, stops, and reverses direction.
A planet moving across the sky appears turn backwards.

questions.text: The explanation for retrograde motion in the Ptolomeic universe was

answerChoices.text: Planets are moving in small circles within a larger circle
The planet slowed down, stopped, and reversed direction due to the force of gravity.
The earth changed direction while orbiting.
The sun changed the direction it is spinning.

questions.text: The explanation for retrograde motion in the Copernican universe is:

answerChoices.text: The earth changed direction while orbiting.
The sun changed the direction it is spinning.
The planet slowed down, stopped, and reversed direction due to the force of gravity.
Planets are moving in small circles within a larger circle.

questions.text: For most of history, people believed the planets must move in circles. Kepler discovered that:

answerChoices.text: They move in ellipses, not circles, but the ellipses are nearly circular.
They move in ellipses, not circles, and the ellipses are highly eccentric (non-circular).
They move in a square, not a circle.
They did indeed move in circles.

questions.text: From the Renaissance to the 2006 IAU meeting, the term "planet" had a very unclear definition. The closest thing to a definition was:

answerChoices.text: A large spherical mass orbiting the sun
A large spherical mass orbiting the earth
An object that appears in a different points in the celestial sphere
Any large mass in space
